author: Jasper Hamill
title: Land Rover unveils see through caravan designed to make life safer for motorists - and horses
text:
Land Rover has designed a new see-through caravan which will make motoring safer for trailer-towing drivers and their animal passengers.
The British car designer unveiled its " Transparent Trailer " today, which features cameras fitted on the back so video can be transmitted to the driver's rear view mirror in real time.
It follows in the tyre prints of Samsung's see through juggernaut , which helps nervous drivers see the road ahead before attempting an dangerous overtaking manoeuvre.
The innovation is likely to be particularly useful for horse owners, who delight in tugging their equine acquaintances around the nation in great ungainly trailers.
Dr Wolfgang Epple, director of research and technology at Jaguar Land Rover, said: "When you are overtaking it is instinctive to check your mirrors, but if you are towing your vision is often restricted with large blind spots.
"Our Transparent Trailer project is researching how we could offer a view out of the vehicle unrestricted by your trailer, no matter what its size or shape.
"Our prototype system offers a very high quality video image with no distortion of other cars or obstructions.
"This means the driver would have exactly the right information to make safe and effective decisions when driving or manoeuvring,making towing safer and less stressful."
The hi-tech trailer has also been fitted with a system called Check Cargo, which alerts drivers whenever their pony is in peril.
Get Surrey Accident: The horses ran loose after their trailer flipped over
Strong-willed stallions are known to break out of horse trailers , with horseplay recently causing chaos on an unloved stretch of the M25.
They also end up getting thrown about in trailers and badly bashed about.
But the new technology will detect a problem with "load of boxes, antique furniture, a classic car or even a valuable horse".
Pressure pads fitted to the floor of the trailer will detect excessive movement, allowing the driver to look at the contents of their caravan to see if all is well.
Dr Epple added: "Many of our customers tow valuable cargoes for business and pleasure, so we are researching a range of technologies that would enhance the towing experience and make it safer - for the driver and even their horses.
"A permanent video feed through to the dashboard from the trailer has the potential to distract the driver from the road ahead.
"Instead we are developing a more intelligent system that is able to detect a problem with the horse in the trailer and warn the driver.
"The video is then available for owners to view the inside of the trailer and support a decision to pull over and check the horse."
Getty Foal play: Transporting ponies can be perilous
Dr Emma Puntis, am associate of the British Animal Rescue and Trauma Care Association, is planning to study Land Rover's new system in a bid to "better understand horse stress and distress during travel".
"Whether it is to help prevent road accidents and injuries to horse and handler, or even to simply ensure your horse arrives at its destination stress free, I'm sure every owner would like to learn how to reduce stress for their horse during travel.
"Gaining a better understanding of the environment inside the trailer, and the horse's reaction to it, would make the animal more comfortable during travel and ensure the horse is capable of performing to the best of its ability."
Land Rover's new technology will be shown off at the Burghley Horse Trials from September 3.
